chapter9.title: Raja Vidya Raja Guhya Yoga (The Yoga of Supreme Knowledge and Secret)
chapter9.description: In Chapter 9, Krishna reveals the most confidential knowledge of his divine nature, the power of devotion, and the path to liberation through surrender to him. He explains his all-pervading presence, the futility of ritualistic worship without devotion, and the inclusivity of his grace, assuring Arjuna that sincere devotion leads to eternal union with him, guiding his warrior duties toward spiritual fulfillment.

slok1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे। ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।9.1।।
slok1.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca idaṁ tu te guhyatamaṁ pravakṣyāmy anasūyave, jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yaj jñātvā mokṣyase ’śubhāt
slok1.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: To you, who are free from envy, I shall now declare the most confidential knowledge, along with realization, knowing which you will be liberated from all inauspiciousness.
slok1.explanation: Krishna begins Chapter 9 by promising Arjuna the most secret knowledge (raja guhya) and realization, which will free him from misfortune. Addressing Arjuna as free from envy, Krishna emphasizes the purity needed to receive this wisdom. For Arjuna, this knowledge is vital to transcend the war’s moral dilemmas, ensuring his actions align with divine truth and lead to liberation.

slok2.sanskrit: राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम्। प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम्।।9.2।।
slok2.transliteration: rāja-vidyā rāja-guhyaṁ pavitram idam uttamam, pratyakṣāvagamaṁ dharmyaṁ susukhaṁ kartum avyayam
slok2.meaning: This is the king of knowledge, the king of secrets, supremely pure, directly realized, righteous, easy to practice, and imperishable.
slok2.explanation: Krishna describes this knowledge as the highest (raja vidya), most confidential (raja guhya), pure, directly experiential, aligned with dharma, easy to practice, and eternal. This sloka highlights the accessibility and supremacy of devotion. For Arjuna, it assures that this knowledge is practical for his warrior life, enabling him to perform duties with spiritual clarity and achieve lasting liberation.

slok3.sanskrit: अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप। अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि।।9.3।।
slok3.transliteration: aśraddadhānāḥ puruṣā dharmasyāsya parantapa, aprāpya māṁ nivartante mṛtyu-saṁsāra-vartmani
slok3.meaning: Those who lack faith in this path, O scorcher of foes, failing to attain Me, return to the cycle of birth and death.
slok3.explanation: Krishna warns that those without faith in this divine knowledge remain trapped in the cycle of samsara (birth and death), unable to reach him. This sloka emphasizes the necessity of faith. For Arjuna, it underscores the importance of trusting Krishna’s teachings to transcend the war’s transient outcomes, ensuring his actions lead to spiritual liberation rather than worldly entanglement.

slok4.sanskrit: मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना। मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः।।9.4।।
slok4.transliteration: mayā tatam idaṁ sarvaṁ jagad avyakta-mūrtinā, mat-sthāni sarva-bhūtāni na cāhaṁ teṣv avasthitaḥ
slok4.meaning: By Me, in My unmanifest form, this entire universe is pervaded. All beings exist in Me, but I am not in them.
slok4.explanation: Krishna explains his all-pervading, unmanifest nature, sustaining all beings, yet transcendent, not contained within them. This sloka highlights his paradoxical immanence and transcendence. For Arjuna, it reveals Krishna as the essence of the battlefield and beyond, encouraging him to see his duties as part of Krishna’s divine order, acting without attachment to material outcomes.

slok5.sanskrit: न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्। भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः।।9.5।।
slok5.transliteration: na ca mat-sthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogam aiśvaram, bhūta-bhṛn na ca bhūta-stho mamātmā bhūta-bhāvanaḥ
slok5.meaning: Nor do beings exist in Me—behold My divine Yoga! I am the supporter and creator of beings, yet My Self does not dwell in them.
slok5.explanation: Krishna clarifies that while he supports and creates all beings, they do not limit him, showcasing his divine Yoga (mystic power). This sloka deepens the understanding of his transcendence. For Arjuna, it suggests that the war’s events, though sustained by Krishna, do not bind him, urging Arjuna to act with detachment, knowing Krishna’s supreme nature governs all.

slok6.sanskrit: यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान्। तथा सर्वं भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय।।9.6।।
slok6.transliteration: yathākāśa-sthito nityaṁ vāyuḥ sarvatra-go mahān, tathā sarvaṁ bhūtāni mat-sthānīty upadhāraya
slok6.meaning: As the mighty wind, ever-present in space, moves everywhere, so all beings rest in Me—understand this.
slok6.explanation: Krishna uses the analogy of wind moving in space to explain how all beings exist within him, yet he remains unaffected. This sloka illustrates his all-encompassing nature. For Arjuna, it implies that the battlefield’s chaos is contained in Krishna, encouraging him to perform his duties with the awareness of Krishna’s supreme presence, reducing personal involvement.

slok7.sanskrit: सर्वं भूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम्। कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम्।।9.7।।
slok7.transliteration: sarvaṁ bhūtāni kaunteya prakṛtiṁ yānti māmikām, kalpa-kṣaye punas tāni kalpādau visṛjāmy aham
slok7.meaning: At the end of a cosmic cycle, O son of Kunti, all beings enter My material nature; at the cycle’s beginning, I manifest them again.
slok7.explanation: Krishna describes the cosmic cycle where beings merge into his material nature at dissolution and are recreated at the cycle’s start. This sloka highlights his role as the cosmic creator. For Arjuna, it contextualizes the war’s impermanence within the grand cycle, urging him to focus on eternal devotion to Krishna to transcend these temporal events.

slok8.sanskrit: प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः। भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात्।।9.8।।
slok8.transliteration: prakṛtiṁ svām avaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punaḥ punaḥ, bhūta-grāmam imaṁ kṛtsnam avaśaṁ prakṛter vaśāt
slok8.meaning: Controlling My own nature, I manifest this multitude of beings again and again, helplessly under the sway of material nature.
slok8.explanation: Krishna explains that he orchestrates creation repeatedly through his material nature, with beings subject to its influence. This sloka emphasizes his sovereignty over creation. For Arjuna, it suggests that the war’s events are part of this cosmic play, encouraging him to act as Krishna’s instrument, free from attachment, knowing all is under divine control.

slok9.sanskrit: न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय। उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु।।9.9।।
slok9.transliteration: na ca māṁ tāni karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya, udāsīnavad āsīnam asaktaṁ teṣu karmasu
slok9.meaning: These actions do not bind Me, O Dhananjaya, for I remain detached, like one indifferent, unattached to those actions.
slok9.explanation: Krishna states that cosmic actions (creation, dissolution) do not bind him, as he remains detached and neutral. This sloka underscores his transcendence over karma. For Arjuna, it models the ideal of detached action, encouraging him to fight in the war without attachment to outcomes, emulating Krishna’s impartiality to align with divine will.

slok10.sanskrit: मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम्। हेतुनानेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तति।।9.10।।
slok10.transliteration: mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sa-carācaram, hetunānena kaunteya jagad viparivartati
slok10.meaning: Under My supervision, material nature produces the moving and non-moving. Because of this, O son of Kunti, the universe revolves.
slok10.explanation: Krishna explains that material nature operates under his oversight, creating all beings, driving the universe’s cycles. This sloka highlights his role as the cosmic overseer. For Arjuna, it assures that the war’s events are governed by Krishna’s will, urging him to act as a warrior with trust in divine supervision, focusing on devotion rather than control.

slok11.sanskrit: अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम्। परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम्।।9.11।।
slok11.transliteration: avajānanti māṁ mūḍhā mānuṣīṁ tanum āśritam, paraṁ bhāvam ajānanto mama bhūta-maheśvaram
slok11.meaning: Fools deride Me when I assume a human form, ignorant of My supreme nature as the great Lord of all beings.
slok11.explanation: Krishna laments that the ignorant mock his human form, unaware of his supreme divine nature as the Lord of all. This sloka corrects misconceptions about his incarnation. For Arjuna, it deepens his reverence for Krishna as more than his charioteer, inspiring him to dedicate his warrior duties to the supreme Lord, recognizing his divine essence.

slok12.sanskrit: मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः। राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः।।9.12।।
slok12.transliteration: moghāśā mogha-karmāṇo mogha-jñānā vicetasaḥ, rākṣasīm āsurīṁ caiva prakṛtiṁ mohinīṁ śritāḥ
slok12.meaning: With vain hopes, futile actions, and deluded knowledge, their minds bewildered, they embrace a demonic and delusive nature.
slok12.explanation: Krishna describes those who, due to ignorance, pursue futile goals and actions, adopting demonic tendencies under delusion. This sloka contrasts the ignorant with devotees. For Arjuna, it warns against succumbing to delusion in the war, urging him to embrace Krishna’s teachings to avoid futile pursuits and act with divine clarity and purpose.

slok13.sanskrit: महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः। भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम्।।9.13।।
slok13.transliteration: mahātmānas tu māṁ pārtha daivīṁ prakṛtim āśritāḥ, bhajanty ananya-manaso jñātvā bhūtādim avyayam
slok13.meaning: But great souls, O Partha, embracing My divine nature, worship Me with single-minded devotion, knowing Me as the imperishable origin of all beings.
slok13.explanation: Krishna praises great souls who, aligned with his divine nature, worship him with unwavering devotion, recognizing him as the eternal source. This sloka highlights the path of bhakti. For Arjuna, it inspires him to emulate these souls, dedicating his warrior actions to Krishna with single-minded devotion, ensuring spiritual alignment and liberation.

slok14.sanskrit: सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः। नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते।।9.14।।
slok14.transliteration: satataṁ kīrtayanto māṁ yatantaś ca dṛḍha-vratāḥ, namasyantaś ca māṁ bhaktyā nitya-yuktā upāsate
slok14.meaning: Always chanting My glories, striving with firm resolve, bowing to Me with devotion, they worship Me, ever united.
slok14.explanation: Krishna describes devotees who constantly glorify him, strive with determination, and offer obeisance with devotion, remaining perpetually connected. This sloka outlines devotional practices. For Arjuna, it suggests integrating such devotion into his warrior life—glorifying Krishna through actions, ensuring his duties become a form of worship, leading to spiritual union.

slok15.sanskrit: ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते। एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम्।।9.15।।
slok15.transliteration: jñāna-yajñena cāpy anye yajanto mām upāsate, ekatvena pṛthaktvena bahudhā viśvato-mukham
slok15.meaning: Others worship Me through the sacrifice of knowledge, in oneness, in diversity, or in manifold forms, as the all-pervading reality.
slok15.explanation: Krishna describes those who worship him through knowledge, perceiving him as one, distinct, or manifold, recognizing his universal presence. This sloka accommodates varied spiritual approaches. For Arjuna, it validates his path of devotion, encouraging him to see Krishna’s presence in all aspects of the war, performing his duties as a sacrificial offering to the divine.

slok16.sanskrit: अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम्। मन्त्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम्।।9.16।।
slok16.transliteration: ahaṁ kratur ahaṁ yajñaḥ svadhāham aham auṣadham, mantro ’ham aham evājyam aham agnir ahaṁ hutam
slok16.meaning: I am the ritual, I am the sacrifice, the offering, the herb, the mantra, the clarified butter, the fire, and the oblation.
slok16.explanation: Krishna identifies himself as the essence of all sacrificial elements—rituals, offerings, mantras, and fire—revealing his omnipresence in Vedic practices. This sloka emphasizes his centrality in worship. For Arjuna, it suggests that his warrior duties, when offered to Krishna, become a sacred sacrifice, transforming his actions into a means of divine connection and liberation.

slok17.sanskrit: पिताहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः। वेद्यं पवित्रमोङ्कार ऋक्सामयजुरेव च।।9.17।।
slok17.transliteration: pitāham asya jagato mātā dhātā pitāmahaḥ, vedyaṁ pavitram oṅkāra ṛk-sāma-yajur eva ca
slok17.meaning: I am the father, mother, creator, and grandfather of this universe, the knowable, the purifier, the syllable Om, and the Rig, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.
slok17.explanation: Krishna declares himself the origin and essence of the universe, the ultimate object of knowledge, the sacred Om, and the Vedas. This sloka underscores his all-encompassing divinity. For Arjuna, it reinforces Krishna’s supreme authority, inspiring him to dedicate his warrior actions to the source of all creation, ensuring they align with divine purpose.

slok18.sanskrit: गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत्। प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम्।।9.18।।
slok18.transliteration: gatir bhartā prabhuḥ sākṣī nivāsaḥ śaraṇaṁ suhṛt, prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ sthānaṁ nidhānaṁ bījam avyayam
slok18.meaning: I am the goal, sustainer, lord, witness, abode, refuge, friend, origin, dissolution, foundation, treasure, and the imperishable seed.
slok18.explanation: Krishna lists his roles as the ultimate destination, sustainer, witness, refuge, friend, and eternal source of all existence. This sloka portrays his multifaceted divine nature. For Arjuna, it presents Krishna as his ultimate ally and refuge, encouraging him to surrender his warrior burdens to Krishna, acting with the assurance of divine support and guidance.

slok19.sanskrit: तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च। अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन।।9.19।।
slok19.transliteration: tapāmy aham ahaṁ varṣaṁ nigṛhṇāmy utsṛjāmi ca, amṛtaṁ caiva mṛtyuś ca sad asac cāham arjuna
slok19.meaning: I give heat, I withhold and send rain, I am immortality and death, being and non-being, O Arjuna.
slok19.explanation: Krishna describes his control over natural forces (heat, rain) and his identity as both immortality and death, existence and non-existence. This sloka highlights his omnipotence. For Arjuna, it reveals Krishna’s mastery over life and death, urging him to fight fearlessly in the war, trusting that all outcomes—victory or loss—are within Krishna’s divine domain.

slok20.sanskrit: त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते। ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोकमश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान्।।9.20।।
slok20.transliteration: trai-vidyā māṁ soma-pāḥ pūta-pāpā yajñair iṣṭvā svar-gatiṁ prārthayante, te puṇyam āsādya surendra-lokam aśnanti divyān divi deva-bhogān
slok20.meaning: Those who follow the three Vedas, purified by drinking soma and performing sacrifices, worship Me to attain heaven. They reach the divine realm of Indra and enjoy celestial pleasures.
slok20.explanation: Krishna describes Vedic ritualists who worship him for heavenly rewards, attaining Indra’s realm and enjoying divine pleasures. This sloka contrasts ritualistic worship with true devotion. For Arjuna, it warns against seeking temporary gains through his warrior victories, urging him to dedicate his actions to Krishna for eternal liberation rather than fleeting rewards.

slok21.sanskrit: ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति। एवं त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते।।9.21।।
slok21.transliteration: te taṁ bhuktvā svarga-lokaṁ viśālaṁ kṣīṇe puṇye martya-lokaṁ viśanti, evaṁ trayī-dharmam anuprapannā gatāgataṁ kāma-kāmā labhante
slok21.meaning: Having enjoyed the vast heavenly realm, when their merit is exhausted, they return to the mortal world. Thus, those who follow Vedic rituals, desiring pleasures, attain a cycle of coming and going.
slok21.explanation: Krishna explains that ritualists, after enjoying heavenly pleasures, return to earth when their merits expire, trapped in samsara. This sloka critiques desire-driven worship. For Arjuna, it emphasizes the impermanence of worldly victories, encouraging him to seek Krishna’s eternal grace through devotion, ensuring his warrior actions lead to liberation, not cyclic rebirth.

slok22.sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते। तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम्।।9.22।।
slok22.transliteration: ananyāś cintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ paryupāsate, teṣāṁ nityābhiyuktānāṁ yoga-kṣemaṁ vahāmy aham
slok22.meaning: For those who worship Me with exclusive devotion, meditating on Me always, I personally ensure their welfare and security.
slok22.explanation: Krishna promises to personally protect and provide for devotees who worship him exclusively, ensuring their spiritual and material welfare (yoga-kshema). This sloka highlights his care for devotees. For Arjuna, it offers assurance that surrendering his warrior duties to Krishna will secure divine protection, enabling him to fight with confidence and spiritual focus.

slok23.sanskrit: येऽप्यन्यदेवताभक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः। तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम्।।9.23।।
slok23.transliteration: ye ’py anya-devatā-bhaktā yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ, te ’pi mām eva kaunteya yajanty avidhi-pūrvakam
slok23.meaning: Even those who faithfully worship other deities, O son of Kunti, worship Me alone, but in an improper way.
slok23.explanation: Krishna states that devotees of other deities ultimately worship him, though indirectly and incorrectly, as he is the supreme source. This sloka reflects his universal acceptance. For Arjuna, it assures that all sincere efforts, even if misguided, reach Krishna, encouraging him to focus his devotion directly on Krishna for the war’s spiritual efficacy.

slok24.sanskrit: अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च। न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते।।9.24।।
slok24.transliteration: ahaṁ hi sarva-yajñānāṁ bhoktā ca prabhur eva ca, na tu mām abhijānanti tattvenātaś cyavanti te
slok24.meaning: I am the enjoyer and Lord of all sacrifices, but those who do not know Me in truth fall down.
slok24.explanation: Krishna declares himself the ultimate recipient and master of all sacrifices, but those unaware of his true nature fail to attain liberation. This sloka emphasizes direct devotion. For Arjuna, it suggests that offering his warrior actions as a sacrifice to Krishna, with true understanding, will ensure spiritual success, avoiding the pitfalls of ignorant worship.

slok25.sanskrit: यान्ति देवव्रता देवान्पितॄन्यान्ति पितृव्रताः। भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम्।।9.25।।
slok25.transliteration: yānti deva-vratā devān pitṝn yānti pitṛ-vratāḥ, bhūtāni yānti bhūtejyā yānti mad-yājino ’pi mām
slok25.meaning: Worshippers of deities go to the deities, those of ancestors go to the ancestors, those of spirits go to the spirits, but My devotees come to Me.
slok25.explanation: Krishna explains that worshippers attain destinations based on their focus—deities, ancestors, or spirits—but his devotees reach him. This sloka contrasts temporary goals with eternal union. For Arjuna, it emphasizes that dedicating his warrior efforts to Krishna ensures the highest destination, urging him to prioritize devotion over lesser aims in the war.

slok26.sanskrit: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति। तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः।।9.26।।
slok26.transliteration: patraṁ puṣpaṁ phalaṁ toyaṁ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati, tad ahaṁ bhakty-upahṛtam aśnāmi prayatātmanaḥ
slok26.meaning: Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, flower, fruit, or water, I accept that offering from a pure-hearted devotee.
slok26.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the simplicity and sincerity of devotion, accepting even humble offerings if given with love. This sloka highlights the accessibility of bhakti. For Arjuna, it suggests that his warrior actions, offered with pure devotion to Krishna, are as valuable as any sacrifice, transforming his duties into a means of divine connection.

slok27.sanskrit: यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्। यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम्।।9.27।।
slok27.transliteration: yat karoṣi yad aśnāsi yaj juhoṣi dadāsi yat, yat tapasyasi kaunteya tat kuruṣva mad-arpaṇam
slok27.meaning: Whatever you do, eat, offer, give, or practice as austerity, O son of Kunti, do it as an offering to Me.
slok27.explanation: Krishna instructs Arjuna to dedicate all actions—daily tasks, sacrifices, charity, and austerities—to him. This sloka integrates all life activities into devotion. For Arjuna, it transforms his warrior duties into a sacred offering, ensuring that fighting, strategizing, and enduring hardships become acts of worship, leading to spiritual liberation.

slok28.sanskrit: शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः। संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि।।9.28।।
slok28.transliteration: śubhāśubha-phalair evaṁ mokṣyase karma-bandhanaiḥ, sannyāsa-yoga-yuktātmā vimukto mām upaiṣyasi
slok28.meaning: Thus, you will be freed from the bondage of actions, good and bad, and with a mind disciplined by the Yoga of renunciation, liberated, you will come to Me.
slok28.explanation: Krishna promises that dedicating all actions to him frees one from karma’s bondage, leading to liberation through renunciation and devotion. This sloka emphasizes freedom through surrender. For Arjuna, it assures that offering his warrior actions to Krishna will liberate him from their consequences, ensuring his spiritual union with Krishna beyond the war’s outcomes.

slok29.sanskrit: समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः। ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम्।।9.29।।
slok29.transliteration: samo ’haṁ sarva-bhūteṣu na me dveṣyo ’sti na priyaḥ, ye bhajanti tu māṁ bhaktyā mayi te teṣu cāpy aham
slok29.meaning: I am equal to all beings; none is hateful or dear to Me. But those who worship Me with devotion are in Me, and I am in them.
slok29.explanation: Krishna declares his impartiality toward all beings, yet those who worship him with devotion share a mutual bond, residing in him and he in them. This sloka highlights the intimacy of devotion. For Arjuna, it assures Krishna’s impartial grace, encouraging him to fight with devotion, knowing his sincere efforts forge a special connection with the divine.

slok30.sanskrit: अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजति मां अनन्यभाक्। साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः।।9.30।।
slok30.transliteration: api cet sudurācāro bhajati māṁ ananya-bhāk, sādhur eva sa mantavyaḥ samyag vyavasito hi saḥ
slok30.meaning: Even if the most sinful worships Me with exclusive devotion, he should be considered righteous, for he has rightly resolved.
slok30.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the transformative power of exclusive devotion, stating that even a sinner becomes righteous through sincere worship. This sloka reflects the inclusivity of bhakti. For Arjuna, it offers hope that any moral struggles in the war can be transcended through devotion to Krishna, ensuring his actions are purified and lead to righteousness.

slok31.sanskrit: क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति। कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति।।9.31।।
slok31.transliteration: kṣipraṁ bhavati dharmātmā śaśvac-chāntiṁ nigacchati, kaunteya pratijānīhi na me bhaktaḥ praṇaśyati
slok31.meaning: Quickly he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace. O son of Kunti, declare boldly that My devotee never perishes.
slok31.explanation: Krishna assures that a devoted sinner swiftly becomes righteous, attaining lasting peace, and his devotees never perish. This sloka guarantees the security of devotees. For Arjuna, it provides confidence that his devotion to Krishna will ensure spiritual success, protecting him from the war’s perils and leading to eternal peace through his warrior duties.

slok32.sanskrit: मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः। स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम्।।9.32।।
slok32.transliteration: māṁ hi pārtha vyapāśritya ye ’pi syuḥ pāpa-yonayaḥ, striyo vaiśyās tathā śūdrās te ’pi yānti parāṁ gatim
slok32.meaning: O Partha, even those of sinful origins—women, vaishyas, and shudras—who take refuge in Me attain the supreme goal.
slok32.explanation: Krishna declares that anyone, regardless of social status or past sins, who surrenders to him attains liberation, emphasizing the universal accessibility of devotion. This sloka breaks social barriers. For Arjuna, it assures that his devotion, despite the war’s moral complexities, guarantees the highest goal, encouraging inclusive faith in Krishna’s grace.

slok33.sanskrit: किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा। अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम्।।9.33।।
slok33.transliteration: kiṁ punar brāhmaṇāḥ puṇyā bhaktā rājarṣayas tathā, anityam asukhaṁ lokam imaṁ prāpya bhajasva mām
slok33.meaning: How much more, then, the holy brahmanas and devoted royal sages? Having attained this transient, joyless world, worship Me.
slok33.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that if even those of lower status attain him, how much more easily can pious brahmanas and royal sages do so, urging Arjuna to worship him in this impermanent world. This sloka motivates devotion. For Arjuna, as a kshatriya, it reinforces his privileged position to worship Krishna, urging him to dedicate his warrior life to divine service for liberation.

slok34.sanskrit: मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु। मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः।।9.34।।
slok34.transliteration: man-manā bhava mad-bhakto mad-yājī māṁ namaskuru, mām evaiṣyasi yuktvaivam ātmānaṁ mat-parāyaṇaḥ
slok34.meaning: Fix your mind on Me, be My devotee, offer sacrifices to Me, bow to Me. Thus, uniting yourself with Me as the supreme goal, you will come to Me.
slok34.explanation: Krishna concludes Chapter 9, instructing Arjuna to focus his mind, devotion, worship, and obeisance on him, promising union with him as the ultimate goal. This sloka encapsulates the essence of bhakti. For Arjuna, it provides a clear directive to integrate devotion into his warrior duties, ensuring that fighting, strategizing, and enduring become acts of surrender, leading to eternal union with Krishna.
